labeled_passages.query: HIV infection increases risk of certain opportunistic infections.
labeled_passages.label: relevant
labeled_passages.text: When you have HIV/AIDS, you’re at higher risk of infections your body would normally be able to fight off. They can also be more severe, more frequent, or both. These infections are called opportunistic infections .
labeled_passages.title: Drugs That Prevent Opportunistic Infections in HIV
labeled_passages.author: Natalie Slivinski

labeled_passages.text: HIV ( human immunodeficiency virus ) puts you at risk of this kind of dementia. It's caused when the virus infects your brain. Over time, this can damage the important nerve cells there.

labeled_passages.query: HIV infection increases risk of certain opportunistic infections.
labeled_passages.label: unrelated
labeled_passages.text: Comorbidities are a new concern for me. Older adults with HIV/AIDS are more likely to develop conditions like cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, and certain cancers. This can be due to a combination of factors, including the HIV virus itself, long-term effects of ART (antiretroviral therapy), and lifestyle factors. They complicate the aging process.
labeled_passages.title: Aging & AIDS

labeled_passages.query: HIV infection increases risk of certain opportunistic infections.
labeled_passages.label: relevant
labeled_passages.text: AIDS dementia complex is caused by the HIV virus itself, not by the opportunistic infections that commonly occur in advanced HIV. We do not know exactly how the virus damages brain cells.

labeled_passages.query: HIV infection increases risk of certain opportunistic infections.
labeled_passages.label: relevant
labeled_passages.text: AIDS stands for acquired immunodeficiency syndrome. It's the most advanced stage of HIV infection. This is usually when your CD4 T-cell count drops below 200 and your immune system is badly damaged. You might get an opportunistic infection, an illness that happens more often and is worse in people who have weakened immune systems. Some of these, such as Kaposi's sarcoma (a form of skin cancer ) and pneumocystis pneumonia (a lung disease), are also considered "AIDS-defining illnesses."
labeled_passages.title: HIV Symptoms
labeled_passages.author: Kendall K. Morgan

labeled_passages.query: HIV infection increases risk of certain opportunistic infections.
labeled_passages.label: relevant
labeled_passages.text: As more and more people with HIV live into old age, doctors have found that chronic HIV infection might raise your risk for other illnesses like heart disease and cancer. Chronic inflammation , which accompanies HIV infection, plays a role in the development of these and other diseases.
labeled_passages.section_heading: How Does Chronic HIV Infection Affect Other Conditions?
labeled_passages.title: Chronic HIV Infection: What to Know
labeled_passages.author: Paul Frysh

labeled_passages.query: HIV infection increases risk of certain opportunistic infections.
labeled_passages.label: relevant
labeled_passages.text: Opportunistic infections take advantage of your body’s weakened defenses. Germs like bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites cause these infections. Better HIV medications have kept these infections at bay for many. But there's still a small chance that you may catch one. If you're not taking these medications, or your condition has advanced to AIDS, your risk is higher.
labeled_passages.title: Dangerous Complications of HIV and AIDS
labeled_passages.author: Christine Yu

labeled_passages.query: HIV infection increases risk of certain opportunistic infections.
labeled_passages.label: relevant
labeled_passages.text:
People with AIDS get sicker with some types of infections than people who don’t have it. This is because their immune system can’t fend them off as well or at all. These opportunistic infections are what cause the signs and symptoms. The most common opportunistic infections that affect people with AIDS include:
Thrush (candidiasis)
Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
Herpes simplex virus (HSV)
Malaria
Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)
Toxoplasmosis (Toxo)
Tuberculosis (TB)
labeled_passages.title: HIV vs. AIDS
labeled_passages.author: Marijke Vroomen Durning, RN

labeled_passages.query: HIV infection increases risk of certain opportunistic infections.
labeled_passages.label: relevant
labeled_passages.text: Human immunodeficiency virus / acquired immune deficiency syndrome ( HIV / AIDS ). HIV infects and destroys immune system cells that normally fight infections. As the number of immune system cells declines, a person's vulnerability to infections rises steadily.
labeled_passages.title: What Are Immune Deficiency Disorders?
labeled_passages.author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

labeled_passages.query: HIV infection increases risk of certain opportunistic infections.
labeled_passages.label: relevant
labeled_passages.text: CMV was once the most common viral opportunistic infection (an illness that gets worse or happens more often in people with weakened immune systems) tied to HIV. Now, ART can help keep your CD4 count up and your immune system strong. It can also help stop retinitis from coming back.

labeled_passages.query: HIV infection increases risk of certain opportunistic infections.
labeled_passages.label: unrelated
labeled_passages.text:
You might be at high risk for HIV if:
You’re a sexually active man who has sex with men.
Your sexual partner is bisexual.
You have sexual partners who have HIV.
You have multiple sexual partners.
You have sex with partners whose HIV status is unknown.
You have sex in exchange for money or something else.
You are getting treatment for hepatitis, tuberculosis, or sexually transmitted diseases such as chlamydia, syphilis, or gonorrhea.
You or your sexual partners inject drugs.
labeled_passages.section_heading: Who Should Get an HIV Test?

labeled_passages.label: unrelated
labeled_passages.text: HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is the virus that causes AIDS (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome). The virus weakens a person's ability to fight infections and cancer. People with HIV are said to have AIDS when the virus makes them very sick and they develop certain infections or cancers.

labeled_passages.query: HIV infection increases risk of certain opportunistic infections.
labeled_passages.label: relevant
labeled_passages.text: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV): The virus that causes AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome). HIV weakens a person's ability to fight infections and cancer. People with HIV are said to have AIDS when the virus makes them very sick and they develop certain infections or cancers. A person gets HIV when an infected person's body fluids (blood, semen, fluids from the vagina or breast milk) enter their bloodstream. The virus can enter the blood through linings in the mouth, anus, or sex organs (the penis and vagina), or through broken skin.
labeled_passages.title: Sex Glossary

labeled_passages.query: HIV infection increases risk of certain opportunistic infections.
labeled_passages.label: relevant
labeled_passages.text: Toxoplasmosis is a common infection of the central nervous system in people with advanced HIV . It’s caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii . ( T. gondii ). You’re at a higher risk for toxoplasmosis if you aren’t getting proper treatment for your condition. That’s because HIV can weaken your immune system. This makes it harder for your body to fight infections.
labeled_passages.title: HIV and Toxoplasmosis: What to Know
labeled_passages.author: Alexandra Benisek

labeled_passages.query: HIV infection increases risk of certain opportunistic infections.
labeled_passages.label: relevant
labeled_passages.text:
You're more likely to get certain infections if you have HIV because the virus can damplen your immune system. But ART can prevent this and lower your infection risk. Some infections that you may get include:
Viral infections such as herpes and shingles, which are treated with rest and antiviral meds.
Bacterial infections such as tuberculosis or pneumonia, which are treated with antibiotics.
Fungal infections such as thrush or pneumocystis pneumonia, which are treated with antifungal meds.
Parasitic infections such as toxoplasmosis, which may need long-term treatment.
labeled_passages.title: Antiretroviral Therapy (ART): Understanding HIV and AIDS Medications
labeled_passages.author: Kendall K. Morgan
